general.headline: Principal and CEO, Haileybury | Chairman, Haileybury International School Tianjin | International Education Strategist
general.description:
•  Currently the Principal and CEO of Haileybury - the largest independent school in Australia with more than 4000 students across four campuses. 

Haileybury 2018 Australian School of the Year
Haileybury 2018 Australian Primary School of the Year - non Government

•  Appointed a member of the new Council for International Education which will oversee Australia’s first National Strategy for International Education 2025.

•  Established the first Sino-Australian school - the Haileybury International School (Tianjin). Haileybury opened a campus in China in 2013 and also delivers education in seven partner schools in China, Timor-Leste and the Philippines.

•  Established Melbourne’s first vertical school – Haileybury City.

•  Director of Haileybury Foundation – an entity committed to providing an affordable education to students from every background.

•  Twenty years experience in education with a strong focus on international engagement, curriculum development, teacher performance appraisal and change management. Noted for driving a commitment to academic excellence, social justice and an international outlook.

•  Author and lecturer on international affairs, globalization, education, leadership and transforming schools.

•  Successful career as a professional cricketer and a journalist before entering education.  

•  Board member of the International Education Association of Australia, a board member of the Australian-Davos Connection Education Council, a member of the Australia India Education Council, and a member of the Australia China High-Level Dialogue.  

•  In 2015 Derek received the Monash University Education Distinguished Alumni Award.

jobs.description:
Haileybury is the largest independent school in Australia with 4000+ students on four campuses in Melbourne – Berwick, Brighton, Keysborough and Melbourne City.

Haileybury is renowned for its strong academic performance across all year levels, it’s acclaimed parallel education model for girls and boys and award-winning teachers and academic program. 

Haileybury is also the largest Australian secondary education provider into Asia with 8 partner schools in China in which it delivers the VCE.  Haileybury also delivers the VCE in Timor-Leste in partnership with Dili International School and in The Philippines in partnership with The Australian International School.

general.headline: Director at Future Schools Alliance
general.description:
We support school leaders to be heroes within their communities, by building future focused
      
      schools that students and their families love to be a part of.

jobs.description: Supporting transformational change in schools

Drawing on the latest research and his unique experiences at TC, Peter is collaborating with educational leaders, schools and other institutions from across the world with the aim to effect widespread educational reform. 
Peter is an experienced keynote speaker at International Conferences, has featured on ’60 minutes’  ‘The Project’ and his TedX presentation has been viewed 230,000 times. In March he copresented a 40 minute session with Sir Ken Robinson and Dan Haesler at the Future Schools Conference. 
Peter will continue his work on implementing alternative models of tertiary entrance with Swinburne and other Universities as well as creating greater awareness and supports around students with dyslexia.
Peter is now consulting to schools and other institutions through Hutton Consulting in the areas of  Innovation and Change Management, Leadership Development, Culture Development and Futures Planning.

Over an 8 year period, the Leadership Team and I transformed TC from a school of last resort and just 286 students, twice directed to close by the Regional Director, to a thriving learning community of over 1100, now recognised by HundrED in Finland as one of the 100 most innovative schools in the world. TC has its own consultancy arm, comprising student and staff representatives, to encourage and support other schools to take on innovative practice.

This was my first teaching position within the State System. The learning curve was
      very steep. I did not know how little I really knew about educational theory until this
      time. It caused me to question a lot of my assumptions, particularly around equity and
      
      the importance of universal high quality educational provision for all.

At 29 years of age and the fourth youngest member of staff, this was a challenge, but one that I relished. Working with the Principal, Philip Grutzner who was only 36, we revitalised the school from one on the verge of bankruptcy, and on a pedagogy based on 1950’s thinking, to a school so in demand that we enrolled a foetus in my final year, such was the level of demand for places.

In my second year of teaching I was appointed Head of House with responsibility for the overall student management of 150 students. I also started an Army Cadet Unit which grew to 90 cadets and is still in operation today. This was a key event in my educational development, as it showed me the enormous potential for self-governance and leadership development within large groups of young people, when given the opportunity and a little adult support.

schools.description: My Master's Degree taught me that those with post graduate qualifications might know the theory but often lack the skills and ability to put these theories into practice. It did however open my eyes to the power of research.

I discovered a passion for teaching and regained my love of learning,  thanks to innovative educator John Loughran, then Teaching and Learning Tutor and now Professor and Dean of Education at Monash University.

As a natural entrepreneur, I now learnt the theory of how money, business and marketing works. On top of my studies, I ran my own Small Property Development Company, a Tree Lopping business and held a myriad of part time jobs during this time…often simultaneously. Developing these theoretical and practical business skills has been invaluable in progressing my career in Education.

general.headline: Academic Literacy Teacher/ Accelerate Australia Director
general.description: Dalal teaches Academic English at a university college in Sydney. Dalal's background is teaching scientific literacy in secondary schools. Dalal is an established education scholar in the area of curricular justice and has presented at both local and international conferences on this issue. Dalal has currently published her first book, an academic monograph on Australia's health system titled, "The Medicare Nightmare: the great Australian tragedy" which focuses significantly on health literacy. The key focus of Dalal's work is to invest in and improve Australia's education system- which is something that she is deeply passionate about. This is why she also directs Accelerate Australia, an organisation that both assesses the impact of the Australian Curriculum on Australian Society and complements it.

general.headline: Director | Founder | Owner - anzuk and Scoot Education
general.description:
My professional experience has been built from a career in education and recruitment that spans over 25 years. Growing up in a large family I was taught the value of collaboration, relationships, integrity and character. I have taken these values through business and life. In 1993 I took the opportunity to attend Ballarat University to complete a PE teaching degree. A few years later I find myself teaching in London. It was the opportunity of a lifetime and an experience I will cherish forever. 

Upon making the decision to head home to start a new life I was lucky enough to fall into Education Recruitment. A desire to be different and do something better has now turned into my daily obsession (other than my wife, children and the odd spot of golf...which I do not play enough of anymore)

It's interesting how the journey of life plays out. Today we support 130 staff around the globe. Over 400,000 children per week are educated by an anzuk team member.  

Its been a privilege to watch our business and people grow since 2004. Its a privilege to get up every day knowing that what we do makes a massive impact across the global education marketplace. Make every lesson count....they are too valuable to waste.

At anzuk we are guided by a unique set of core values BE GREAT. Belief, Exceptional, Growth, Relationships, Empower, Attitude and Team. We exist to create exceptional experiences in education. Our culture is owned by everyone at anzuk.

general.headline: Managing Director at Prolearning Pty Ltd
general.description:
The Research Australia Development & Innovation Institute (RADII) serves the education and community sectors. 

RADII addresses gaps in the services required to support the development and learning of young people during their schooling. 

RADII also undertakes research in partnership with schools and community organisations in the areas of its primary focus. 

RADII’s primary objective is to provide schools and communities with access to advanced performance enhancement, research and knowledge management services. 

RADII provides access to a range of services that are taken-for-granted in the commercial sector, but for reasons of price and configuration are not readily accessible to schools and community organisations. Industrial strength technologies underpin these new services, but the delivery platforms are developed from the ground up to address the workflow and mode of operation in schools and community organisations. 



SPECIALISATION

RADII focuses on developing the capacity of schools and community organisations to capture and understand critical intelligence about local issues, through:

• Leading-edge strategies for supporting learning

• Integration of assessment into teaching and learning

• Improving the effectiveness of teaching & learning

• Industrial-strength virtual platforms for schools, training and other phases of education.

• Using artificial intelligence to reduce the administrative workload of teachers.

RADII's services make extensive use of telecommunications technologies and Internet platforms using Artificial Intelligence strategies and real-time support to reach out to all communities.

Integrated data capture systems utilise communication by Email, SMS, Fax, and 'push' notification technologies, to gather realtime data via the simultaneous deployment of Mobile Apps, Interactive Voice Recording, and online platforms in multiple languages.

general.headline: CEO, The Odyssey Program & Inspire for Girls - In-school workshops for adolescent boys and girls
general.description:
I started The Odyssey Program and Inspire for Girls, in response to the lack of social dialogue about what it means to be a young man and woman in today’s society.

The workshops discuss how boys and girls are bombarded with images, stories and a culture that suggest how males and females should look, behave, feel and be.

The program aims to unpack these messages, offer different role models and argues that it is the qualities of a person that make up who they are.

I have a Bachelors Degree in Social Work and a Masters in Counselling, both obtained from The University of South Australia.

My qualified team work all over Australia and consist of: Luke Bain, Nadia Boscaini, Nicola Dingle, James Gibbs, Jamie Linke and Darren Venn who are all committed to supporting teens to be their best selves.

The aim of the programs are to inspire people, especially teenagers to live their best lives.

For more information on the programs, please contact odyssey program@hotmail.com.au or visit http://odysseyprogram.com.au or http://inspireforgirls.com.au

jobs.description:
Inspire for Girls helps girls learn more about themselves and each other and inspires them to celebrate their uniqueness.

Our in-school workshops are designed to address the concerns of adolescent girls growing up in today's society. 

Our team has constructed a range of informative and interactive programs, that discuss how women are presented in the media, how friendship issues can be addressed respectfully and how to have healthy relationships with themselves and each other. 

Our 7 programs provide teenage girls with an opportunity to learn and participate in activities that questions media myths, provides girls with strategies to navigate social media, body image, bullying and self esteem issues. 

We believe girls are intrinsically beautiful and given positive tools, information, support and care, they will flourish into their best selves.

For more information about this program, visit http://inspireforgirls.com.au

We want to empower teenage boys to develop into healthy, responsible and positive young men.

The Odyssey Program challenges teenage boys to think about what kind of man they want to be and encourage them to work towards being the best version of themselves.

Our in-school workshops are designed to address the concerns of adolescent boys growing up in today's society. We operate nation wide to assist boys to be the men they really want to be.

Our team has constructed a range of informative and interactive workshops, that deconstruct medias perception of masculinity, discuss issues surrounding girls and problems they might experience with friends. 

Our 11 programs provide teenage boys with an opportunity to learn and participate in activities that questions media myths, provides tools and strategies to manage healthy and respectful relationships and offers insight and advice on how to navigate the stages of their journey into manhood.

We believe in the inherent goodness of each young man as we challenge them to see through illusions and to discover their own true sense of self and purpose in life.

For more information about the program, please visit http://odysseyprogram.com.au
Presentations to a wide audience on health and mental health issues.

Developed the training package of Person Centred thinking within the Skill Set of
      
      Disability with Active Support Focus.
Counselling

general.headline: Education & Welfare Manager at Racing Queensland
general.description:
Originally from Dubbo I have been around horses all my life.  I began my career as a jockey three decades ago, and have developed a strong national network with people in (and associated with), the racing industry over an eighteen-year successful career.  

My talent for building relationships and utilising my ‘eye for opportunity’ enabled my transition from jockey to training liaison officer and then Manager at the Department of Education and New Apprenticeship Centres where I nurtured mutually beneficial partnerships to deliver quality outcomes, reduced risk, and grew market share. Ten years ago I transitioned from the DET to Racing NSW, as General Manager of Workforce Development, Education, Employment, Industry Welfare and Safety. 

I enjoy implementing changes and improving the Industry’s position, driving education, developing workforce development plans and country racing strategies. I oversee the financial management of my department and reports and am responsible for safety, licensing, infrastructure and community benefits realisation projects. 

I love Racing, and everything to do with Racing. I am also a family man, and an ordinary golfer.

I learnt as a young jockey that there is no place for second best. I live by this philosophy and this is demonstrated by my dedication and determination to continuously improve both personally and professionally. I strive for the highest possible standards in customer service, products and operational activity. 

►I am available at mclogue@me.com if you ever want to talk about anything Racing. You can also find me at @MauriceLogue on Twitter.

general.headline: Educator, Researcher, Author and Leader of the Berry Street Education Model at the Berry Street Childhood Institute
general.description:
Tom Brunzell (MS, EdM, PhD candidate) has experience as a teacher, school leader, researcher and education advisor in New York City and Melbourne.  Currently he is the Senior Advisor, Education and the Leader of the Berry Street Education Model at the Berry Street Childhood Institute, Victoria.   Tom presents internationally on topics of transforming school cultures, high expectations for differentiated instruction, trauma-informed practice, wellbeing and the application of positive psychology, and effective school leadership.  He is also a PhD candidate at the University of Melbourne, Melbourne Graduate School of Education studying trauma-informed pedagogy, positive psychology, and their impacts on workplace meaning.

The Berry Street Education Model provides schools with the training, curriculum and strategies to engage the most challenging students. This education initiative is different because it is research-informed, multifaceted and systemic. It is unique because it educates schools and their leaders in our trauma-informed positive education approach to reinforce and sustain cognitive and behavioural change, thereby re-engaging the young person in learning and progressing their academic achievement.

tbrunzell@berrystreet.org.au 
More information: www.childhoodinstitute.org.au/EducationModel

general.headline: PhD, Author of Gratitude in Education: A Radical View; Senior Lecturer in Education, University of Tasmania
general.description: I am a researcher and facilitator of processes that can assist us to reach our highest potential and believe that the practice of gratitude is key to this endeavour. I am passionate about transformation of education so that we can teach truly awake students and I believe that we need to focus on deep, profound, simple, straightforward, time and cost-effective ways of doing this. I am also passionate about transformation at an organisational level and believe that if leaders are able to openly discuss the dilemmas they find in overcoming resentment (the opposite of gratitude) and are supported in taking up gratitude practices, they can truly shine and lead from deep within. I love the opportunity to speak to large groups but also to work one-on-one in a coaching relationship.

jobs.description:
Dr Kerry Howells is a teacher educator in the University of Tasmania (UTAS) Faculty of Education, teaching in the areas of professional studies, practitioner research, and teacher leadership. Over the past two decades Kerry has been researching the role of gratitude in enhancing teaching and learning processes at all levels of education. She has published several academic papers that report on the findings of her research on the role of gratitude in the areas of school leadership, pre-service teacher education, and school education. Her book, Howells, K. (2012) Gratitude in Education: A Radical View is the first full text to be written on this topic, and has been hailed by reviewers around the world as “ground-breaking”. Kerry draws on a range of case studies in different levels of education – from primary to university - to outline a phenomenology of gratitude when it is placed in different contexts, and furthers our understanding of both the complexities and possibilities of gratitude for both education and other fields. Many in the field of Positive Psychology have been using this text in their practice and teaching courses. In her most recent work, Kerry has been exploring the implications for education of cultural differences in expressions of gratitude. She has conducted her investigation in the areas of Australian Aboriginal and Maori cultures, and following on from her time as a visiting scholar at the University of South Africa in 2014, in indigenous African culture. In June 2015 Kerry was invited by an NGO to speak at the United Nations on the relationship between gratitude and human dignity.

Kerry is also a public speaker and welcomes invitations to share her research. Her most recent invited speaker presentations on gratitude can be viewed at: 
TEDx talk : https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gzfhPB_NtVc
Mind and its Potential, Sydney: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=47hd5HTQV1E
Positive Schools Conferences: http://www.positiveschools.com.au

general.headline: Professor of Positive Psychology at University of Melbourne
general.description: Professor Dianne Vella-Brodrick (PhD) is Deputy Director and Head of Research at the Centre for Positive Psychology at the Melbourne Graduate School of Education, University of Melbourne. She is the inaugural Director of the Master of Applied Positive Psychology program (2013 – 2015) and is a registered psychologist and a Member of the Australian Psychological Society and College of Health Psychologists. She founded the Positive Psychology Network in Australia and has served as Treasurer and Secretary of the International Positive Psychology Association (IPPA) and is currently on the IPPA Council of Advisors.  Dianne has been an inaugural Editor in Chief of the Psychology of Well-Being: Theory, Research and Practice journal (2011-2016) and has Co-Directed the 2008, 2010 and 2014 Australian positive psychology and well-being conferences. She has published widely, and presents regularly at conferences.  She serves on numerous research advisory boards, regularly reviews scientific papers for leading journals and has received around $2.5 million in research funding. Dianne’s research interests include the development and evaluation of well-being programs, particularly in the areas of positive education and performance optimisation.  She specialises in innovative mixed method designs which utilise the latest technology, experience sampling method and psychophysiological indices of well-being. Her research has a special focus on young people. She also integrates ethical and professional practice issues in much of her work and is currently the Ethics Chair at the Melbourne Graduate School of Education. Dianne also has extensive experience with scale development and psychometric testing having been involved in the development of numerous well-being scales including the Wuzzup app and Wellbeing Profiler.

general.headline: I'm a University researcher who turns my science into Strength-Based strategies to help you thrive.
general.company: Psychologist, Researcher & Speaker on Strength-Based Parenting & #PositiveEducation
general.description:
Lea Waters, PhD is one of the world’s leading experts on Positive Education, Positive Organizations and Strength-Based Parenting and Teaching.

Lea is the President of the International Positive Psychology Association, serves on the World Happiness Council’s Council of Happiness & Education, and is the founding Director of the Centre for Positive Psychology at the University of Melbourne, where she’s worked for more than 20 years.

Lea helps parents, educators and organizations make a small switch that makes a big difference in overall wellbeing.

As humans, we’re wired to focus on the negative and zoom in on what’s “off.” Lea proposes a better way for doing things. She says we can short-circuit our negative defaults by making a mental switch that flicks to shift our attention from weaknesses to strengths, and from the negative to positive news around us.

In her TEDx talk “Warning: Being Positive Is Not For The Faint Hearted”, Lea explores how we can spread positive messages in an effort to override the dominant message of fear and scarcity and make a collective difference in the world by spreading hope and happiness.

And in her book “The Strength Switch” Lea says that the strength-based approach gives us the power to live the good life by drawing on our most abundant inner resources (our strengths!). 

Lea is passionate about helping people all over the world make the Strength Switch. Her ‘Positive Detective’ and ‘Visible Wellbeing” programs are being used by schools worldwide. 

Lea has been featured in The Atlantic, The Wall Street Journal, The Guardian, and more. As a researcher, she’s published more than 95 scientific journal articles.

Her top strengths include: humor, curiosity and kindness.

To learn more about working with Lea visit: www.LeaWaters.com.

Categories: #StrengthSwitch, #PositiveDetective, #Strengths, #StrengthBasedParenting, #PositivePsychology, #Speaker, #Wellbeing, #Education, #Teaching, #Parenting,  #PositiveEducation, #EducationSpeaker

general.headline: Director and Proprietor, Positive Psychology Solutions Pty Ltd
general.description:
Nev is the author of the acclaimed Positive Leadership and Workplace Health program for the Australian Public Service, written in 2007. 

Nev entered the workforce as a graduate Electrical Engineer in 1972 and quickly moved into managerial / marketing roles. These experiences produced a desire to know more about human motivation, and to understand why some people seemed to thrive while others suffered and/or failed to fulfill their potential. To help answer these questions Nev return to university study and obtained an honours degree in Psychology in 1998. 

Nev then went on to post graduate study at the University of Sydney where occupational stress and anxiety became his focus. During the three years he spent there he had the opportunity to teach psychology and statistical subjects at Sydney University’s Cumberland campus and discovered his passion for both psychology and teaching. It was however, some time later when he stumbled across the teachings of Martin Seligman and other scholars in the field of Positive Psychology that he found most of the answers to the questions he had been asking for some time. 

Nev left the Australian Public Service in 2014 to form his own business. He now delivers a range of developmental and support programs for industry and has a busy private practice focusing on helping individuals deal with both workplace issues and/or mental health conditions.

general.headline: Positive Change expert, author, speaker, consultant, coach
general.description:
My name is Paige Williams, I am a positive change solutionary using the science of wellbeing to create change and improve performance with leaders, with organizations and at scale.

With strengths in strategic thinking, creativity and ideation, I help leaders create sustainable positive change with performance impact by uncovering strategic solutions to complex challenges. Drawing from the fields of positive psychology, neuroscience, leadership and change, my own research, and over 15 years international business leadership experience, I provide clear, practical, evidence-based solutions to accelerate positive change, foster wellbeing and achieve strategic goals.

A part-time lecturer with the Centre for Positive Psychology at the University of Melbourne, I am a PhD, with research examining change pathways and processes to create wellbeing at work and a Master Trainer in positive psychology having trained with Prof. Martin Seligman.  

I am passionate about creating positive change with individuals, organizations and communities by helping them discover the choices for change they have available and realize their capacity to succeed, flourish and thrive.

jobs.description:
In my consultancy services I use the science of wellbeing to create positive sustainable
      change with individuals, with organizations and at scale.
      

    Creating and sustaining change can be challenging and exhausting. Using evidence
      from fields such as positive psychology, neuroscience and leadership I develop
      strategy and implementation plans  that embed wellbeing in the process of change to
      drive performance and achieve strategic goals. My clients include, Specsavers, Swisse,
      Transport Accident Commission, the Magistrates Court of Victoria, Committee for
      
      Geelong, City of Ballarat, Adroit Insurance and Geelong Grammar School.

jobs.companyName: University of Melbourne, Centre for Positive Psychology
jobs.description: As the subject coordinator for a variety of courses at Masters and Professional Certificate levels within the Centre for Positive Psychology, Melbourne Graduate School of Education, I develop curriculum that translates the latest research in ways that enables my students to understand and apply it in their own lives and with their organisations or clients. My current research interests lie in developing and testing a theoretical framework for positive organisational change and exploring how wellbeing can be intentionally developed within and at the systems level - a research field we are tentatively calling Positive Systems Science.

As a consultant to the Centre for Workplace Leadership at the University of Melbourne I designed and developed content for 'LeaderShift', an online leadership development program that supports the Workplace Leadership Competency Standard.  Comprising 27 modules that map the competencies within the Standard, Leadershift was launched at the Future of Work conference in April 2016.

In addition, I was the lead consultant in a culture change project for the Magistrates Court of Victoria, in which I developed an evidenced-based change strategy and a detailed and staged five to seven year implementation plan with milestones across the organization.

I was the project manager of a specific initiative focused on embedding positive psychology into the orgnization, the purpose of which was to establish the school as a ‘positive institution’.  Embedding the tenets of positive psychology, appreciative inquiry and authentic leadership within the philosophy and practices of the School, this involved changing culture, structures, mindsets and behaviours.

I was responsible for the development and delivery of the inaugural Positive Education
      Training Conferences with full accountability for strategy, planning and implementation
      of this complex and strategically critical project, including stakeholder management,
      
      funding, health and safety, legal and financial aspects and operations.

I developed and implemented communications strategy for the whole school, including
      media, website, advertising, publications, brand management and events, and
      
      managed a team of multi-disciplinary staff and a department budget in excess of $1M.

schools.description: Placed within the positive organisational research paradigm, my research analyses the influence of employee psychological capital - their hope, optimism, resilience and efficacy - on their perceptions and evaluations of organisation culture and feelings of happiness at work. Specifically, it examines attitude change as the underlying causal mechanism for the relationships.
Graduate Certificate in Change Management
BA (Hons) Business Studies

general.headline: Business Consultant, Company Director and Finance and Treasury Professional
general.description:
I’m a highly motivated business consultant, company director and finance and treasury professional who loves helping businesses work towards sustainable growth, coupled with strong governance and risk management.

I am inquisitive by nature and seldom let questions go unanswered or ideas left unexplored.

I have extensive experience working in the real estate sector, and working in various finance roles in capital-intensive industries.  Recently I've been involved with the professional association and education sectors and previously with sports administration.  

I have worked with business of all sizes from the very large to the very small. And I've contributed at the coal-face right through to board level.

My consultancy and coaching practice – Truro Partners – is devoted to helping businesses firstly build a solid foundation and then to develop and expand on a sustainable basis.

I seek advisory, coaching and company director roles where I can bring my tenacity, my extensive experience and my skill set into your business.

jobs.description:
Truro Partners is a business consultancy and coaching service providing high-level
      finance and treasury advisory services, and business coaching aimed at small to
      
      medium-sized enterprises (SME's)

We fundamentally understand that all business owners long to have choices when it comes to their business – whether they’re looking to build, capitalise or sell. Yet many find themselves at various times along their business journey clouded with uncertainty, stuck in the day-to-day intrigues of running their business, and dealing with innumerable people challenges.
​
Embarking on a process with us enables business owners to feel as though they are getting back in control of things and having the energy in the business a lot calmer, the people more aligned and essentially better informed decisions are being made for improved commercial and cultural performance.

general.headline: Transactions Manager at Dexus

jobs.description:
I began the Coles Graduate program in January 2011 and have had the opportunity to work within various teams of Coles Property. My program is comprised of four 6 month rotations and I am currently on my third rotation. 

My first six months at Coles was within Property Lease Management, working within different areas with exposure to Lease Renewal, Property Compliance and Lease Management. As my first rotation it was the perfect introduction to Retail Leasing, as I learnt how to calculate percentage rent, outgoings and how to read/interpret a lease. I also got experience in handling property disputes, market reviews of rents, exercise of options, calculating occupancy costs and reviewing lease terms. 

In August 2011 I commenced my second rotation in Capital Transactions and was exposed to negotiation, property strategy and analysis work. In particular, I was involved with feasibility analysis, strategic review of locations within NSW for potential sites, understanding town planning regulation, sourcing property ownership information and analysis of recent sales to determine a market value.

I commenced my third rotation in Property Development in February 2012 and currently, I am continuing my learning and development within the program and the company.
